results.description: The GraphQL response returns a schema-related error that discloses internal API structure (the Query.cards field and that it does not accept an 'input' argument). This is an information-disclosure/introspection-type leak: even though a dedicated __schema introspection query was not used, verbose error messages reveal schema details that can help an attacker enumerate types, fields, and expected arguments. Impact is primarily informational (helps reconnaissance), so severity is set to LOW. Recommend disabling verbose schema errors in production, mask or genericize error messages, and restrict GraphQL introspection in non-development environments.

results.description: The GraphQL response includes explicit field suggestions ("Did you mean 'name'?") for misspelled fields. This is clear evidence the server exposes schema hints in error messages, which leaks information about available types/fields. Attackers can use these suggestions to enumerate the schema or discover valid field names even if introspection is restricted. This is an information disclosure issue (field_suggestions). Remediation: suppress detailed GraphQL error messages in production, disable or remove suggestion logic, and return generic error messages or map errors to safe application-level errors.

results.detection_name: LLM: GraphQL schema disclosure (introspection via error messages)
results.description: The GraphQL response returns detailed error messages that reveal schema elements (the existence of Query.cards and a Card type). Although this is not a direct full __schema introspection response, the errors disclose field and type names which enable reconnaissance and schema enumeration. Such information can be used to craft further queries or attacks. Recommend suppressing detailed error messages in production, disabling introspection for unauthenticated users, or implementing error handling that does not reveal schema structure.

results.description: The GraphQL response includes a suggestion ('Did you mean "name"?') when an incorrect field ('nam') was queried. This reveals schema information (valid field names/types) which can aid attackers in enumerating the API and crafting targeted queries. Such detailed error suggestions are an information disclosure risk. Mitigation: disable suggestion hints and detailed schema errors in production (return generic error messages), enforce strict error handling, and restrict introspection or require authentication/authorization for schema-discovering operations.

results.description: The GraphQL error message exposes schema details by naming the root field 'Query.cards' and indicating it does not accept an 'input' argument. This leaks internal schema information (field and argument names), which can be used by attackers to enumerate the API and craft more targeted queries or attacks. Although this is not an immediate destructive vulnerability, it is an information disclosure (schema discovery) that facilitates further attack vectors. Mitigation: suppress or sanitize detailed GraphQL errors in production (return generic error messages), enable strict error handling, and consider rate-limiting or auth checks on introspection and error responses.

Cannot query field "queryType" on type "Card". Did you mean "energyType"?
Field "types" must not have a selection since type "[String]" has no subfields.

results.detection_name: LLM: Introspection (schema disclosure via error messages)
results.description: The GraphQL response leaks schema information through detailed error messages and suggestions. Messages reveal type and field names (e.g. Card, energyType, Query.cards), argument names (input), and the types of fields (e.g. types is [String]). Although the response is not an explicit __schema introspection result, this kind of detailed error leakage effectively enables schema enumeration and is equivalent to an introspection-like information disclosure. This information can be used by an attacker to craft targeted queries and find further weaknesses. Recommended mitigations: disable or sanitize verbose GraphQL errors in production, avoid returning schema suggestions, restrict or disable the introspection endpoint where appropriate, and enforce authentication/authorization and rate limiting on GraphQL endpoints.
results.evidence: Error messages returned by GraphQL API: "Cannot query field \"queryType\" on type \"Card\". Did you mean \"energyType\"?", "Unknown argument \"input\" on field \"Query.cards\".", "Field \"types\" must not have a selection since type \"[String]\" has no subfields.", plus type/field name suggestions.

Did you mean \"energyType\"?", "Unknown argument \"input\" on field \"Query.cards\".", "Field \"types\" must not have a selection since type \"[String]\" has no subfields.", plus type/field name suggestions.
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL response leaks schema information through detailed error messages and suggestions. Messages reveal type and field names (e.g. Card, energyType, Query.cards), argument names (input), and the types of fields (e.g. types is [String]). Although the response is not an explicit __schema introspection result, this kind of detailed error leakage effectively enables schema enumeration and is equivalent to an introspection-like information disclosure. This information can be used by an attacker to craft targeted queries and find further weaknesses. Recommended mitigations: disable or sanitize verbose GraphQL errors in production, avoid returning schema suggestions, restrict or disable the introspection endpoint where appropriate, and enforce authentication/authorization and rate limiting on GraphQL endpoints.

This is an information-disclosure issue (field_suggestions) because it leaks schema details that aid attackers in enumerating available fields and crafting more effective queries. While not an immediate remote-execution or data exfiltration flaw by itself, it lowers the barrier for further probing and targeted attacks. Recommended mitigations include suppressing or sanitizing suggestion details in errors, disabling detailed error messages in production, or configuring the GraphQL server to avoid returning field-name suggestions.

results.description: The API returned a GraphQL error that exposes internal schema details: the root type (Query) and a field name (cards), and that it does not accept an argument named 'input'. This is an information-disclosure / introspection-style leak because an attacker can learn schema structure from error messages and use that knowledge to craft targeted queries or probe for other fields and types. While this is not an immediate critical vulnerability by itself (no data was returned and no execution occurred), it increases attack surface and can aid enumeration. Recommend disabling verbose GraphQL errors in production, return generic error messages, and/or restrict introspection and schema exposure (e.g., via authentication, query depth limits, query complexity limits, and error masking).

This is a field_suggestions/information disclosure issue: an attacker can use typo queries to enumerate likely field names and learn schema details. Mitigations: disable or suppress suggestion text in errors, return generic error messages, restrict GraphQL introspection in production, and implement access controls/logging to limit schema discovery.
